content.description: To estimate the proportion of Europeans who walk for exercise at least <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes a week, data were collected from a random sample of <math alttext="27,919" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>27</mn><mtext>,919</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> people from Europe. The <math alttext="95" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval created from the data was <math alttext="0.856 comma 0.864" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mn>0.856</mn> </mrow> <mo>,</mo> <mrow> <mn>0.864</mn> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>.
content.question: Which of the following is an appropriate interpretation of the confidence interval?

choices.label: The probability that a randomly selected person from Europe walks for exercise at least <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes a week is <math alttext="0.95" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The proportion of Europeans who walk between <math alttext="0.856" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>0.856</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="0.864" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.864</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minute a week for exercise is <math alttext="0.95" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

There is a <math alttext="95%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> chance that the sample proportion of Europeans who walk for exercise at least <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes a week is between <math alttext="0.856" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.856</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.864" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.864</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Between <math alttext="85.6%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>85.6</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="86.4%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>86.4</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of all Europeans walk for exercise at least <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes a week.

We can be <math alttext="95%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> confident that the proportion of all Europeans who walk for exercise at least <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes a week is between <math alttext="0.856" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.856</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.864" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.864</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: We can be <math alttext="95%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> confident that the proportion of all Europeans who walk for exercise at least <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes a week is between <math alttext="0.856" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.856</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.864" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.864</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 6.3: Justifying a Claim Based on a Confidence Interval for a Population Proportion

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
